Master Constable Pythagoras Gyptes Panelion Dipsas Two or more characters speaking at once Scintilla Fauilla Prologue

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.p: Most high and happy Princess, we must tell you a tale of the Man in the Moon, which if it seem ridiculous for the method, or superfluous for the matter, or for the means incredible, for three faults we can make but one excuse. It is a tale of the Man in the Moon.

It was forbidden in old time to dispute of Chimera, because it was a fiction, we hope in our times none will apply pastimes, because they are fancies; for there liveth none under the Sun, that knows what to make of the Man in the Moon. We present neither Comedy, nor Tragedy, nor story, nor anything, but that whosoever heareth may say this, Why here is a tale of the Man in the Moon.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: I find Eumenides in all things both variety to content, and satiety to glut, saving only in my affections, which are so stayed, and withal so stately, that I can neither satisfy my heart with love, nor mine eyes with wonder. My thoughts are stitched to the stars, which being as high as I can see, thou mayst imagine how much higher they are than I can reach.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.p: If you be enamoured of anything above the Moon, your thoughts: are ridiculous, for that things immortal are not subject to affections, if allured or enchanted with these transitory things under the Moon, you show yourself senseless, to attribute such lofty titles, to such love trifles.

sp.speaker: End
sp.p: My love is placed neither under the Moon nor above.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: I hope you be not sotted upon the man in the Moon.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: No but settled, either to die, or possess the Moon herself.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Is Endimion mad, or do I mistake? do you love the Moon Endimion?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Eumenides the Moon.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p:
There was never any so peevish to imagine the Moon either capable of affection, or shape of a Mistress: for as impossible it is to make love fit to her humour which no man knoweth, as a coat to her form, which continueth not in one bigness whilst she is measuring. Cease off Endimion to feed so much upon fancies. That melancholy blood must be purged, which draweth you
to a dotage no less miserable than monstrous.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: My thoughts have no veins, and yet unless they be let blood, I shall perish.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: But they have vanities, which being reformed, you may be restored.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p:
O fair Cynthia, why do others term thee unconstant, whom I have ever found unmovable? Injurious time, corrupt manners, unkind men, who finding a constancy not to be matched, in my sweet Mistress, have christened her with the name of wavering, waxing, and waning. Is she inconstant that keepeth a settled course, which since her first creation altereth not one minute in her moving? There is nothing thought more admirable, or commendable in the Sea, than the ebbing and flowing, and shall the Moon, from whom the Sea taketh this virtue, be accounted fickle for increasing and decreasing? Flowers in there buds, are nothing worth till they be blown, nor blossoms accounted till they be ripe fruit, and shall we then say they be changeable, for that they grow from seeds to leaves, from leaves to buds, from buds to their perfection? then, why be not twigs that become trees, children that become men, and Mornings that grow to Evenings, termed wavering, for that they continue not at one stay? Aye but Cynthia, being in her fulness, decayeth, as not delighting in her greatest beauty, or withering when she should be most honoured. When malice cannot object anything, folly will , making that a vice, which is the greatest virtue. What thing my Mistress excepted) being in the pride of her beauty, and latter minute of her age, that waxeth young again? Tell me Eumenides, what is he that having a Mistress of ripe years, and infinite virtues, great honours, and unspeakable beauty, but would wish that she might grow tender again? getting youth by years, and never-decaying beauty, by time, whose fair face, neither
the Summers blaze can scorch, nor Winters blast chap, nor the numbering of years breed altering of colours. Such is my sweet Cynthia whom time cannot touch, because she is divine, nor will offend because she is delicate. O Cynthia if thou shouldest always continue at thy fulness, both Gods and men would conspire to ravish thee. But thou to abate the pride of our affections, dost detract from thy perfections, thinking it sufficient, if once in a month we enjoy a glimpse of thy majesty, and then, to increase our griefs, thou dost decrease thy gleams, coming out of thy royal robes, wherewith thou dazzlest our eyes, down into thy swathe clouts, beguiling our eyes. And then

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Stay there thou that commitest Idolatry, wilt straight blaspheme, if thou be suffered. Sleep would do thee more good than speech: the Moon heareth thee not, or if she do, regardeth thee not.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Vain Eumenides, whose thoughts never grow higher than the crown of thy head. Why troublest thou me, having neither head to conceive the cause of my love, or a heart to receive the impressions? follow thou thine own fortunes, which creep on the earth, and suffer me to fly to mine, whose fall though it be desperate, yet shall it come by daring. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Without doubt Endimion is bewitched, otherwise in a man of such rare virtues, there could not harbour a mind of such extreme madness. I will follow him, lest in this fancy of the Moon, he deprive himself of the sight of the Sun.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p:
Treacherous and most perjured Endimion, is Cynthia the sweetness of thy life, and the bitterness of my
death? What revenge may be devised so full of shame, as my thoughts are replenished with malice? Tell me Floscula if falseness in love can possibly be punished with extremity of hate. As long as sword, fire, or poison may be hired, no traitor to my love shall live unrevenged. . Were thy oaths without number, thy kisses without measure, thy sighs without end, forged to deceive a poor credulous Virgin, whose simplicity had been worth thy favour and better fortune? If the Gods sit unequal beholders of injuries, or laughers at Lovers deceits, then let mischief be as well forgiven in women, as perjury winked at in men.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: Madam, if you would compare the state of Cynthia with your own, and the height of Endimion his thoughts, with the meanness of your fortune, you would rather yield than contend, being between you and her no comparison, and rather wonder than rage at the greatness of his mind, being affected with a thing more than mortal.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: No comparison Floscula? and why so ? is not my beauty divine, whose body is decked with fair flowers, and veins are Vines, yielding sweet liquor to the dullest spirits, whose ears are Corn, to bring strength, and whose hears are grass, to bring abundance? Doth not Frankincense, and Myrrh breath out of my nostrils, and all the sacrifice of the Gods, breed in my bowels? Infinite are my creatures, without which , neither thou nor Endimion, nor any could love, or live.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p:
Endimion But know you not fair Lady, that Cynthia governeth all things? Your grapes would be but dry husks, your Corn but chaff, and all your virtues vain, were it not Cynthia that preserveth the one in the bud, and nourisheth the other in the blade, and by her influence both comforteth all things, and by her authority commandeth all creatures; suffer then Endimion
to follow his affections, though to obtain her be impossible, and let him flatter himself in his own imaginations, because they are immortal.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Loath I am Endimion thou shouldest die, because I love thee well, and that thou shouldest live it grieveth me, because thou lovest Cynthia too well. In these extremities what shall I do? Floscula no more words, I am resolved. He shall neither live, nor die.

sp.speaker: Flos.
sp.p: A strange practice, if it be possible.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Yes, I will entangle him in such a sweet net, that he shall neither find the means to come out, nor desire it. All allurements of pleasure will I cast before his eyes, insomuch that he shall slake that love which he now voweth to Cynthia, and burn in mine, of which he seemeth careless. In this languishing, between my amorous devises, and his own loose desires, there shall such dissolute thoughts take root in his head, and over his heart grow so thick a skin, that neither hope of preferment, nor fear of punishment, nor counsel of the wisest, nor company of the worthiest, shall alter his humour, nor make him once to think of his honour.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: A revenge incredible, and if it may be, unnatural.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: He shall know the malice of a woman, to have neither mean, nor end, and of a woman deluded in love, to have neither rule, nor reason. I can do it, I must, I will . All his virtues will I shadow with vices, his person (ah sweet person) shall he deck with such rich Robes, as he shall forget it is his own person, his sharp wit (ah wit too sharp, that hath cut off all my joys) shall he use, in flattering of my face, and devising Sonnets in my favour. The prime of his youth and pride of his time, shall be spent in melancholy passions, careless behaviour, untamed thoughts, and unbridled affections.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: When this is done what then, shall it continue till his death, or shall he dote forever in this delight?

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Ah Floscula, thou rendest my heart in sunder, in putting me in remembrance of the end.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: Why if this be not the end, all the rest is to no end.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Yet suffer me to imitate Juno, who would turn lovers to beasts on the earth, though she knew afterwards they should be stars in heaven.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: Affection that is bred by enchantment, is like a flower that is wrought in silk, in colour and form most like , but nothing at all in substance or savour.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: It shall suffice me if the world talk that I am favoured of Endimion.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: Well, use your own will , but you shall find that love gotten with witchcraft, is as unpleasant, as fish, taken with medicines unwholesome.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Floscula, they that be so poor that they have neither net nor hook, will rather poison dow than pine with hunger: and she that is so oppressed with love, that she is neither able with beauty, nor wit to obtain her friend, will rather use unlawful means, than try untolerable pains. I will do it.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: Then about it. Poor Endimion , what traps are laid for thee, because thou honourest one that all the world wondereth at. And what plots are cast to make thee unfortunate, that studiest of all men to be the faithfullest.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Now our Masters are in love up to the ears, what have we to do, but to be in knavery, up to the crowns.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: O that we had Sir that Tophas that brave Squire, in the midst of our mirth, et ecce autem will; you see the devil?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Epi.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: I brooke not this idle humour of love, it tickleth not my liver, from whence the Love-mongers in former age seemed to infer they should proceed.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Love sir may lie in your lungs, and I think it doth, and that is the cause you blow, and are so pursy.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Tush boy, I think it but some devise of the Poet to get money.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: A Poet? what is that ?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Dost thou not know what a Poet is?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Why fool, a Poet is as much as one should say, a Poet. But soft, yonder be two Wrens, shall I shoot at them?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: They are two lads.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Larks or Wrens, I will kill them.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Larks? are you blind? they are two little boys.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Birds, or boys, they are both but a pittance for my breakfast, therefore have at them, for their brains must as it were embroider my bolts.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Stay your courage valiant Knight, for your wisdom is so weary that it stayeth itself.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Why Sir Tophas have you forgotten your old friends?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Friends Nego argumentum?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And why not friends?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p:
Because Amicitia (as in old Annals we find) is inter pares , now my pretty companions, you shall see how unequal you be to me, but I will not cut you quite
off, you shall be my half friends, for reaching to my middle, so far as from the ground to the waste I will be your friend.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Learnedly. But what shall come of the rest of your body, from the waist to the crown?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: My children quod supra vos nihil ad vos, you must think the rest immortal, because you cannot reach it.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Nay I tell ye my Master is more than a man.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: And thou less than a mouse.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: But what be you two?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I am Samias, page to Endimion.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: And I Dares, page to Eumenides

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Of what occupation are your Masters.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Occupation, you Clown, why they are honourable, and Warriors.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Then are they my prentices.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Thine, and why so ?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: I was the first that ever devised war, and therefore by Mars himself given me for my Arms a whole Armoury, and thus I go as you see, clothed with Artillery, it is not Silks (milksops) nor Tissues, nor the fine wool of Ceres, but iron, steel, swords, flame, shot, terror, clamour, blood, and ruin, that rocks asleep my thoughts, which never had any other cradle, but cruelty. Let me see, do you not bleed?

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Why so ?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Commonly my words wound.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: What then do your blows?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Not only confound, but also confound.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: How darest thou come so near thy Master Epi. Sir Tophas spare us .

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p:
You shall live. You Samias because you are little. You Dares because you are no bigger, and both of you, because you are but two; for commonly I kill by the dozen, and have for every particular adversary, a
peculiar weapon.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: May we know the use for our better skill in war?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: You shall. Here is a burbolt for the ugly beast the blackbird.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: A cruel sight.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Here is the Musket, for the untamed, (or as the vulgar sort term it) the wild Mallard.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: O desperate attempt.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Nay, my Master will match them.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Aye if he catch them.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Here is a spear and shield, and both necessary, the one to conquer, the other to subdue, or overcome the terrible Trout, which although he be under the water, yet tying a string to the top of my spear, and an engine of iron to the end of my line, I overthrow him, and then herein I put him.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: O wonderful war. Dares, didst thou ever hear such a dolt?

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: All the better, we shall have good sport hereafter, if we can get leisure.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: Leisure, I will rather lose my Masters service than his company, look how he struts; But what is this, call you it your sword?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: No, it is my Scimitar , which I by construction often studying to be compendious, call my Smiter.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: What, are you also learned sir?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Learned? I am all Mars and Ars.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: Nay, you are all Mass and Ass.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Mock you me? You shall both suffer, yet with such weapons, as you shall make choice of the weapon wherewith you shall perish. Am I all a mass or lump, is there no proportion in me? Am I all Ass? is there no wit in me? Epi prepare them to the slaughter.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p:
As I pray sir hear us speak, we call you Mass,
which your learning doth well understand, is all Man, for Mas maris is a man. Then As as you know) is a weight, and we for your virtues account you a weight.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: The Latin hath saved your lives, the which a world of silver could not have ransomed. I understand you, and pardon you.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Tophas Well Sir Tophas we bid you farewell, and at our next meeting, we will be ready to do you service.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Samias I thank you. Dares I thank you, but especially I thank you both.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: Wisely. Come, next time we will have some pretty Gentlewomen, with us to walk, for without doubt with them he will be very dainty.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Come let us see what our Masters do, it is high time.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Now will I march into the field, where if I cannot encounter with my foul enemies, I will withdraw myself to the River, and there fortify for fish: for there resteth no minute free from fight.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Behold Floscula, we have met with the Woman by chance that we sought for by travel; I will break my mind to her without ceremony or circumstance, lest we lose that time in advice, that should be spent in execution.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: Use your discretion, I will in this case, neither give counsel nor consent, for there cannot be a thing more monstrous, than to force affection by sorcery, neither do I imagine anything more impossible.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p:
Tush Floscula, in obtaining of love, what impossibilities will I not try? and for the winning of Endimion, what impieties will I not practise? Dipsas, whom
as many honour for age, as wonder at for cunning, listen in few words to my tale, and answer in one word to the purpose, for that neither my burning desire can afford long speech, nor the short time I have to stay many delays. Is it possible by herbs, stones, spells, incantation, enchantment, exorcisms, fire, metals, planets, or any practise to plant affection where it is not, and to supplant it where it is?

sp.speaker: Dipsas.
sp.p: Fair Lady, you may imagine that these hoary hairs are not void of experience, nor the great name that goeth of my cunning to be without cause. I can darken the Sun by my skill, and remove the Moon out of her course; I can restore youth to the aged, and make hills without bottoms, there is nothing that I cannot do, but that only which you would have me do, and therein I differ from the Gods, that I am not able to rule hearts, for were it in my power to place affection by appointment, I would make such evil appetites, such inordinate lusts, such cursed desires, as all the world should be filled both with superstitious heats, and extreme love.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Unhappy Tellus, whose desires are so desperate, that they are neither to be conceived of any creature, nor to be cured by any art .

sp.speaker: Dipsas.
sp.p: This I can, breed slackness in love, though never root it out. What is he whom you love, and what she that he honoureth?

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Endimion, sweet Endimion is he that hath my heart, and Cynthia, too too fair Cynthia, the miracle of Nature, of time, of Fortune, is the Lady that he delights in , and dotes on every day, and dies for ten thousand times a day.

sp.speaker: Dipsas.
sp.p: Would you have his love, either by absence or sickness a-slaked. Would you that Cynthia should mistrust him, or be jealous of him without colour?

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: It is the only thing I crave, that seeing my love to Cynthia unspotted, cannot be accepted, his truth to Cynthia (though it be unspeakable) may be suspected.

sp.speaker: Dipsas.
sp.p: I will undertake it, and overtake him, that all his love shall be doubted of, and therefore become desperate: but this will wear out with time, that treadeth all things down but truth.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Let us go.

sp.speaker: Dipsas.
sp.p: I follow.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: O Fair Cynthia O unfortunate Enfimion. Why was not thy birth as high as thy thoughts, or her beauty less than heavenly? or why are not thine honours as rare as her beauty? or thy fortunes as great as thy deserts? Sweet Cynthia, how wouldst thou be pleased, how possessed? will labours (patient of all extremities) obtain thy love? There is no Mountain so steep that I will not climb, no monster so cruel that I will not tame, no action so desperate that I will not attempt. Desirest thou the passions of love, the sad and melancholy moods of perplexed minds, the not to be expressed torments of racked thoughts? Behold my sad tears, my deep sighs, my hollow eyes, my broken sleeps, my heavy countenance. Wouldst thou have me vowed only to thy beauty, and consume every minute of time in thy service, remember my solitary life, almost these seven years, whom have I entertained but mine own thoughts, and thy virtues?What company have I used but contemplation? Whom have I wondered at but thee? Nay whom have I not contemned, for thee? Have I not crept to those on whom I might have trodden, only because thou didst shine upon them? Have not injuries been sweet to me, if thou vouchsafest I should bear them? Have I not spent my golden years in hopes, waxing old with wishing, yet wishing nothing but thy love. With Tellus, fair Tellus, have I dissembled, using her but as a cloak for mine affections, that others seeing my mangled and disordered mind, might think it were for one that loveth me, not for Cynthia, whose perfection alloweth no companion, nor comparison.

In the midst of these distempered thoughts of mine, thou art not only jealous of my truth, but careless, suspicious, and secure: which strange humour maketh my mind as desperate as thy conceits are doubtful. I am none of those Wolves that bark most, when thou shinest brightest. But that fish, (thy fish Cynthia in the flood Aranis) which at thy waxing is as white as the driven snow, and at thy waning, as black as deepest darkness. I am that Endimion (sweet Cynthia) that have carried my thoughts in equal balance with my actions, being always as free from imagining ill, as enterprising; That Endimion, whose eyes never esteemed anything fair, but thy face, whose tongue termed nothing rare but thy virtues, and whose heart imagined nothing miraculous, but thy government. Yea that Endimion, who divorcing himself from the amiableness of all Ladies, the bravery of all Courts, the company of all men, hath chosen in a solitary Cell to live, only by feeding on thy favour, accounting in the world but thyself) nothing excellent, nothing immortal; thus mayst thou see every vain, sinew, muscle, and artery of my love, in which there is no flattery, nor deceit, error, nor art . But soft, here cometh Tellus, I must turn my other face to her like Janus, lest she be as suspicious as Juno.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Yonder I espy Endimion, I will seem to suspect nothing but sooth him, that seeing I cannot obtain the depth of his love, I may learn the height of his dissembling; Floscula and Dipsas, withdraw yourselves out of our sight, yet be within the hearing of our saluting; How now Endimion, always solitary? no company but your own thoughts? no friends but melancholy fancies?

sp.speaker: Endimion.
sp.p: You know (fair Tellus ) that the sweet remembrance of your love, is the only companion of my life, and thy presence, my paradise, so that I am not alone when nobody is with me, and in Heaven itself when thou art with me.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Then you love me Endimion

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Or else I live not Tellus

sp.speaker: Tellus
sp.p: Is it not possible for you Endimion, to dissemble?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Not Tellus, unless I could make me a woman.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Why, is dissembling joined to their sex inseparable? as heat to fire, heaviness to earth, moisture to water, thinness to air?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: No, but found in their sex, as common, as spots upon Doves, Moles upon faces, Caterpillars upon sweet Apples, Cobwebs upon fair windows.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Do they all dissemble?

sp.speaker: Endimion.
sp.p: All but one.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Who is that ?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: I dare not tell. For if I should I say you, then would you imagine my flattery to be extreme, if another, then would you think my love to be but indifferent.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: You will be sure I shall take no vantage of your words. But in sooth Endimion, without more ceremonies, is it not Cynthia?

sp.speaker: Endimion.
sp.p: You know Tellus, that of the Gods we are forbidden to dispute, because their deities come not within the compass of our reasons, and of Cynthia we are allowed not to talk but to wonder, because her virtues are not within the reach of our capacities

sp.speaker: Tellus
sp.p: Why, she is but a woman.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: No more was Venus

sp.speaker: Tellus
sp.p: She is but a virgin.

sp.speaker: Endimion
sp.p: No more was Vesta

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: She shall have an end.

sp.speaker: Endim.
sp.p: So shall the world.

sp.speaker: Tellus
sp.p: Is not her beauty subject to time?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: No more than time is to standing still.

sp.speaker: Tellus
sp.p: Wilt thou make her immortal?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: No, but incomparable.

sp.speaker: Tellus
sp.p: Take heed Endimion, lest like the Wrestler in Olympia, that striving to lift an impossible weight, catched an incurable strain, thou by fixing thy thoughts above thy reach, fall into a disease without all recure? But I see thou art now in love with Cynthia.

sp.speaker: Endim.
sp.p: No Tellus, thou knowest that the stately Cedar, whose top reacheth unto the clouds, never boweth his head to the shrubs that grow in the valley, nor Ivy that climbeth up by the Elm, can ever get hold of the beams of the Sun; Cynthia I honour in all humility, whom none ought, or dare adventure to love, whose affections are immortal, and virtues infinite. Suffer me therefore to gaze on the Moon, at whom, were it not for thyself, I would die with wondering.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p:
Come Samias, didst thou ever hear such a sighing, the one for Cynthia, the other for Semile, and both
for moonshine in the water?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Let them sigh, and let us sing, how say you Gentlewomen, are not our Masters too far in love?

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: Their tongues happily are dipped to the root in amorous words and sweet discourses, but I think their hearts are scarce tipped on the side, with constant desires.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: How say you Faulilla, is not love a lurcher, that taketh men's stomachs away that they cannot eat, their spleen that they cannot laugh, their hearts that they cannot fight, their eyes that they cannot sleep, and leaveth nothing but livers to make nothing but Lovers?

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: Away peevish boy, a rod were better under thy girdle, than love in thy mouth: it will be a forward Cock that croweth in the shell.

sp.speaker: Dares
sp.p: Alas good old Gentlewoman, how it becommeth you to be grave,

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: Fauilla though she be but a spark, yet is she fire.

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: And you Scintilla be not much more than a spark, though you would be esteemed a flame.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: It were good sport to see the fight between two sparks.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Let them to it, and we will warm us by their words.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: You are not angry Fauilla?

sp.speaker: Faui.
sp.p: That is Scintilla, as you list to take it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That , that .

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: This it is to be matched with girls, who coming but yesterday from making of babies, would before tomorrow be accounted Matrons.

sp.speaker: Fauil
sp.p: I cry your Matronship mercy; because your Pantofles be higher with cork, therefore your feet must needs be higher in the insteps: you will be mine elder, because you stand upon a stool, and I on the flower.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Good, good.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Let them alone, and see with what countenance they will become friends.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: Nay, you think to be the wiser, because you mean to have the last word.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Step between them lest they scratch. In faith Gentlewomen, seeing we came out to be merry, let not your jarring mar our jests: be friends, how say you?

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: I am not angry, but it spited me to see how short she was.

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: I meant nothing, till she would needs cross me.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Then so let it rest.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: I am agreed.

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: And I, yet I never took anything so unkindly in my life.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: It is I have the cause, that never offered the occasion.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Excellent and right like a woman.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A strange sight to see water come out of fire.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: It is their property, to carry in their eyes, fire, and water, tears and torches, and in their mouths, honey and gall.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: You will be a good one if you live; but what is yonder formal fellow?

sp.speaker: Dares.
Fauil.
sp.p: We will do our parts.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: But first let us stand aside, and let him use his garb, for all consisteth in his gracing.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Epi,

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: At hand sir.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p:
How likest thou this Martial life, where nothing but blood besprinkleth our bosoms? Let me see
be our enemies fat?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Passing fat: and I would not change this life to be a Lord, and yourself passeth all comparison, for other Captains kill and beat, and there is nothing you kill, but you also eat.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: I will draw out their guts out of their bellies, and tear the flesh with my teeth, so mortal is my hate, and so eager my unstaunched stomach.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: My master thinks himself the valiantest man in the world if he kill a Wren: so warlike a thing he accompteth to take away life, though it be from a Lark.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Epi, I find my thoughts to swell, and my spirit to take wings, insomuch that I cannot continue within the compass of so slender combats.

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: This passeth.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: Why is he not mad?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: No, but a little vainglorious.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Epi.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: I will encounter that black and cruel enemy, that beareth rough and untewed locks upon his body, whose Sire throweth down the strongest walls, whose legs are as many as both ours , on whose head are placed most horrible horns, by nature, as a defence from all harms.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What mean you Master to be so desperate?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Honour inciteth me, and very hunger compeleth me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What is that monster?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: The Monster Ouis. I have said, let thy wits work.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
I cannot imagine it; yet let me see, a black enemy with rough locks, it may be a sheep, and Ouis is a sheep: his Sire so strong, a Ram is a sheeps Sire: that being also an engine of war, horns he hath, and four legs, so
hath a sheep: without doubt this Monster is a black sheep; Is it not a sheep that you mean?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it, that Monster will I kill and sup with.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Come let us take him off. Sir Tophas Sir all hail.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Welcome children, I seldom cast mine eyes so low as to the crowns of your heads, and therefore pardon me that I spake not all this while.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: No harm done, here be fair Ladies come to wonder at your person, your valour, your wit, the report whereof, hath made them careless of their own honours, to glut their eyes and hearts upon yours.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Report cannot but injure me, for that not knowing fully what I am, I fear she hath been a niggard in her praises.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: No gentle Knight, Report hath been prodigal, for she hath left you no equal, nor herself credit, so much hath she told, yet no more than we now see.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: A good wench,

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: If there remain as much pity toward women, as there is in you courage against your enemies, then shall we be happy, who hearing of your person, came to see it, and seeing it, are now in love with it.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Love me Ladies? I easily believe it, but my tough heart receiveth no impression with sweet words. Mars may pierce it, Venus shall not paint on it.

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: A cruel saying.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: There is a girl.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Will you cast these Ladies away, and all for a little love? do but speak kindly.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p:
There cometh no soft syllable within my lips, custom hath made my words bloody, and my heart barbarous: that pelting word love, how waterish it is in my mouth, it carrieth no sound, hate, horror, death, are speeches that nourish my spirits. I like honey but I care not for
the Bees, I delight in music but I love not to play on the Bagpipes, I can vouchsafe to hear the voice of women, but to touch their bodies I disdain it, as a thing childish, and fit for such men as can digest nothing but milk.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: A hard heart, shall we die for your love, and find no remedy.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: I have already taken a surfeit.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Good master pity them.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Pity them Epi? no I do not think that this breast shall be pestered with such a foolish passion. What is that the Gentlewoman carrieth in a chain?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why, it is a Squirrel.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: A Squirrel? O Gods what things are made for money.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Is not this Gentleman overwise?

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: I could stay all day with him, if I feared not to be shent.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: Is it not possible to meet again.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Yes at any time.

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: Then let us hasten home.

sp.speaker: Scint.
sp.p: Sir Tophas the God of war deal better with you, than you do with the God of love.

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: Our love we may dissemble, digest we cannot, but I doubt not but time will hamper you, and help us .

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: I defy time, who hath no interest in my heart: come Epi. let me to the battle with that hideous beast, love is pap and hath no relish in my taste, because it is not terrible.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Indeed a black sheep is a terrible beast, but let us in till another time.

sp.speaker: Fauil.
sp.p: I shall long for that time.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p:
No rest Endimion? still uncertain how to settle thy steps by day, or thy thoughts by night? thy truth is measured by thy fortune, and thou art judged unfaithful because thou art unhappy. I will see if I can beguile
myself with sleep, and if no slumber will take hold in my eyes, yet will I embrace the golden thoughts in my head, and wish to melt by musing: that Ebony, which no fire can scorch, is yet consumed with sweet savours, so my heart which cannot be bent by the hardness of fortune, may be bruised by amorous desires. On yonder bank never grew anything but Lunary, and hereafter I will never have any bed but that bank. O Endimion, Tellus was fair, but what availeth Beauty without wisdom? Nay Endimion she was wise, but what availeth wisdom without honour? She was honourable Endimion, belie her not, aye but how obscure is honour without fortune? Was she not fortunate whom so many followed? Yes, yes, but base is fortune without Majesty: thy Majesty Cynthia all the world knoweth and wondereth at, but not one in the world that can imitate it or comprehend it. No more Endimion, sleep or die; Nay die, for to sleep it is impossible, and yet I know not how it cometh to pass, I feel such a heaviness both in mine eyes and heart, that I am suddenly benumbed, yea in every joint: it may be weariness, for when did I rest? It may be deep melancholy, for when did I sigh? Cynthia, aye so , say Cynthia.

sp.speaker: Dipsas.
sp.p:
Little dost thou know Endimion when thou shalt wake, for hadst thou placed thy heart as low in love, as thy head lieth now in sleep, thou mightst have commanded Tellus, whom now instead of a Mistress, thou shalt find a Tomb. These eyes must seal up by Art, not Nature, which are to be opened neither by Art nor Nature. Thou that layest down with golden locks, shalt not awake until they be turned to silver hairs: and that chin, on which scarcely appeareth soft down, shall be filled with bristles as hard as broom: thou shalt sleep out thy youth and flowering time, and become dry hay before thou knewest thyself green grass, and ready
by age to step into the grave when thou wakest, that was youthful in the Court when thou laidest thee down to sleep. The malice of Tellus hath brought this to pass, which if she could not have entreated of me by fair means, she would have commanded by menacing, for from her gather we all our simples to maintain our sorceries. Fan with this hemlock over his face, and sing the enchantment for sleep, whilst I go in and finish those ceremonies that are required in our Art: take heed ye touch not his face, for the Fan is so seasoned that whoso it toucheth with a leaf shall presently die, and over whom the wind of it breatheth, he shall sleep forever.

sp.speaker: Bagoa.
sp.p: Let me alone, I will be careful. What hap hadst thou Endimion to come under the hands of Dipsas. O fair Endimion, how it grieveth me that that fair face must be turned to a withered skin, and taste the pains of death before it feel the reward of love. I fear Tellus will repent that which the heavens themselves seemed to rue, but I hear Dipsas coming, I dare not repine, lest she make me pine, and rock me into such a deep sleep, that I shall not awaked to my marriage.

sp.speaker: Dipsas.
sp.p: How now, have you finished?

sp.speaker: Bagoa.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Dipsas.
sp.p: Well then let us in , and see that you do not so much as whisper that I did this, for if you do, I will turn thy hairs to Adders, and all thy teeth in thy head to tongues, come away, come away.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Is the report true, that Endimion is stricken into such a dead sleep, that nothing can either wake him or move him?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Too true Madam, and as much to be pitied as wondered at.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: As good sleep and do no harm, as wake and do no good.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: What maketh you Tellus to be so short? the time was Endimion only was.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: It is an old saying Madam, that a waking dog doth afar off bark at a sleeping lion.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.p: It were good Eumenides that you took a nap with your friend for your speech beginneth to be heavy

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Contrary to your nature Semele, which hath been always accounted light.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: What have we here before my face, these unseemly and malapert overthwarts? I will tame your tongues, and your thoughts, and make your speeches answerable to your duties, and your conceits fit for my dignity, else will I banish you both my person and the world.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Pardon I humbly ask; but such is my unspotted faith to Endimion, that whatsoever seemeth a needle to prick his finger, is a dagger to wound my heart.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: If you be so dear to him, how happeneth it you neither go to see him, nor search for remedy for him?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p:
I have seen him to my grief, and sought recure with despair, for that I cannot imagine who should restore him, that is the wonder to all men: your highness, on whose hands the compass of the earth is at command, (though not in possession) may show yourself
both worthy your sex, your nature, and your favour, if you redeem that honourable Endimion, whose ripe years foretell rare virtues, and whose unmellowed conceits promise ripe counsel.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: I have had trial of Endimion, and conceive greater assurance of his age, than I could hope of his youth.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: But timely Madam crooks that tree that will be a cammock, and young it pricks that will be a thorne, and therefore he that began without care to settle his life, it is a sign without amendment he will end it.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Presumptuous girl, I will make thy tongue an example of unrecoverable displeasure, Corsites carry her to the Castle in the Desert, there to remain and weave.

sp.speaker: Cors.
sp.p: Shall she work stories or poetries?

sp.speaker: Cynthia.
sp.p: It skilleth not which , go to , in both, for she shall find examples infinite in either, what punishment long tongues have. Eumenides if either the Soothsayers in Egypt, or the Enchanters in Thessaly, or the Philosophers in Greece, or all the Sages of the world, can find remedy, I will procure it; therefore dispatch with all speed: you Eumenides into Thessalie. You Zontes into Greece, (because you are acquainted in Athens.) You Panton to Egypt, saying that Cynthia sendeth, and if you will , commandeth.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: I On bowed knee give thanks, and with wings on my legs, I fly for remedy.

sp.speaker: Zon.
sp.p: We are ready at your highness command, and hope to return to your full content.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: It shall never be said that Cynthia, whose mercy and goodness filleth the Heavens with joys, and the world with marvels, will suffer either Endmion or any to perish, if he may be protected.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Your Majesties words have been always deeds, and your deeds virtues.

sp.speaker: Cors.
sp.p: Here is the Castle (fair Tellus) in which you must weave, till either time end your days, or Cinthia her displeasure. I am sorry so fair a face should be subject to so hard a fortune, and that the flower of beauty, which is honoured in Courts, should here wither in prison.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Corsites, Cynthia may restrain the liberty of my body, of my thoughts she cannot, and therefore do I esteem myself most free, though I am in greatest bondage.

sp.speaker: Cors.
sp.p: Can you then feed on fancy, and subdue the malice of envy by the sweetness of imagination.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Corsites, there is no sweeter Music to the miserable than despair, and therefore the more bitterness I feel, the more sweetness I find, for so vain were liberty, and so unwelcome the following of higher fortune, that I choose rather to pine in this Castle, than to be a Prince in any other Court.

sp.speaker: Cors.
sp.p: A humour contrary to your years, and nothing agreeable to your sex: the one commonly allured with delights, the other always with sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: I marvel Corsites that you being a Captain, who should sound nothing but terror, and suck nothing but blood, can find in your heart to talk such smooth words, for that it agreeth not with your calling to use words so soft, as that of love.

sp.speaker: Cors.
sp.p: Lady, it were unfit of wars to discourse with women, into whose minds nothing can sink but smoothness; besides, you must not think that Soldiers be so rough hewn, or of such knotty mettle, that beauty cannot allure, and you being beyond perfection enchant.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p:
Good Corsites talk not of love, but let me to
my labour: the little beauty I have, shall be bestowed on my Loom, which I now mean to make my Lover.

sp.speaker: Cors.
sp.p: Let us in , and what favour Corsites can show, shall command.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: The only favour I desire, is now and then to walk.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Epi.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Unrig me. Hey ho.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What is that ?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: An interjection, whereof some are of mourning: as cho, vah

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Thou seest me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Thou hearest me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Thou feelest me.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: And not understandest me?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Tophas
sp.p: Then am I but three quarters of a Noun substantive. But alas Epi, to tell thee the troth, I am a Noun Adjective.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Because I cannot stand without another.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Who is that ?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Dipsas.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Are you in love?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p:
No: but love hath as it were milked my thoughts, and drained from my heart the very substance of my accustomed courage; it worketh in my head like new
Wine, so as I must hoop my sconce with iron, lest my head break, and so I bewray my brains: but I pray thee first discover me in all parts, that I may be like a Lover, and then will I sigh and die. Take my gun, and give me a gown: Cadant arma togae

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Take my sword and shield, and give me beard, brush, and Scissors: bella gerant alii, tu pari semper ama

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Will you be trimmed sir?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Not yet: for I feel a contention within me, whether I shall frame the bodkin beard or the bush. But take my pike and give me pen: dicere que puduit, scribere iussit amor

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I will furnish you sir.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Now for my bow and bolts, give me ink and paper, for my Smiter a pen-knife: for Scalpellum calami, atramentum, charta belli, sint semper studiis arma parata meis

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Sir will you give over wars, and play with that babble called love?

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Give over wars? no Epi, Militat omnis armans, et habet sua castea Cupido.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Love hath made you very eloquent, but your face is nothing fair.

p.foreign: Non formosus erat, sed erat facundus Ulisses.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Nay, I must seek a new Master if you can speak nothing but Verses.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p:
Quicquid conabar dicere versus erat. Epi. I feel all Ouid de arte amandi lie as heavy at my heart as a load of logs. O what a fine thin hair hath Dispsas what a pretty low forehead? What a tale and stately nose? What little hollow eyes? What great and goodly lips? Howe harmless she is being toothless, her fingers fat and short, adorned with long
nails like a Bitter. In how sweet a proportion her cheeks hang down to her breasts like dugs, and her paps to her waste like bags. What a low stature she is, and yet what a great foot she carrieth? How thrifty must she be in whom there is no waste? How virtuous is she like to be, over whom no man can be jealous?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Stay Master, you forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: O Epi. even as a dish melteth by the fire, so doth my wit increase by love.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Pithily, and to the purpose, but what? begin you to nod

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: Good Epi let me take a nap: for as some man may better steal a horse, than another look over the hedge: so divers shall be sleepy when they would fainest take rest.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Whoever saw such a Woodcock, love Dipsas? without doubt all the world will now account him valiant, that ventureth on her , whom none durst undertake. But here cometh two wags.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thy Master hath slept his share.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: I think he doth it because he would not pay me my board wages.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: It is a thing most strange, and I think mine will never return, so that we must both seek new Masters, for we shall never live by our manners.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: If you want Masters, join with me and serve Sir Tophas, who must needs keep more men, because he is toward marriage.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What Epi , where is thy Master?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yonder sleeping in love.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Epi..
sp.p: He hath taken his thoughts a hole lower, and saith, seeing it is the fashion of the world, he will vail bonnet to beauty.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How is he attired?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Lovely.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Whom loveth this amorous Knight?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Dipsas.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: That ugly creature? Why she is fool, a scold, fat, without fashion, and quite without favour.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Tush you be simple, my Master hath a good marriage.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Good? as how?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why in marrying Dipsas, he shall have every day twelve dishes of meat to his dinner, though there be none but Dipsas with him. Four of flesh, four of fish, four of fruit.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: As how Epi?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: For flesh these, Woodcock, Goose, bitter, and rail.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Indeed he shall not miss, if Dipsas be there.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: For fish these, crab, carp, lump, and pouting.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Excellent, for of my word, she is both crabbish, lumpish, and carping.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: For fruit these, fretters, meddlers, artichokes, and Lady longings. Thus you see he shall fare like a King, though he be but a beggar.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Well Epi, dine thou with him, for I had rather fast than see her face. But see thy Master is asleep, let us have a song to wake this Amorous knight.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Sleep is a binding of the senses, love a loosing.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Let us hear him awhile.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p:
There appeared in my sleep a goodly Owl, who sitting upon my shoulder, cried twit, twit, and before mine eyes presented herself the express image
of Dipas. I marvelled what the Owl said, till at the last, perceived twit, twit, to it, to it: only by contraction admonished by this vision, to make account of my sweet Venus.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Sir Tophas, you have overslept yourself.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I No youth, I have but slept over my love.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Love? Why it is impossible, that into so noble and unconquered a courage, love should creep, having first a head as hard to pearce as steel, then to pass to a heart armed with a shirt of male.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Aye but my Master yawning one day in the Sun, love crept into his mouth before he could close it, and there kept such a tumbling in his body, that he was glad to untruss the points of his heart, and entertain Love as a stranger.

sp.speaker: Tophas.
sp.p: If there remain any pity in you, plead for me to Dipsas.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Plead? Nay we will press her to it. Let us go with him to Dipsas, and there shall we have good sport. But sir Tophas when shall we go? for I find my tongue voluble, and my heart venturous, and all myself like myself.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Come Dares, let us not lose him till we find our Masters, for as long as he liveth, we shall lack neither mirth nor meat.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: We will traverse. Will you go sir?

sp.speaker: Eumenides.
sp.p: Father, your sad Music being tuned on the same key that my hard fortune is, hath so melted my mind, that I wish to hang at your mouths end, till life end.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: These tunes Gentleman have I been accustomed with these fifty Winters, having no other house to shroud myself, but the broad heavens, and so familiar with me hath use made misery, that I esteem sorrow my chiefest solace. And welcomest is that guest to me, that can rehearse the saddest tale, or the bloodiest tragedy.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: A strange humour, might I enquire the cause?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: You must pardon me if I deny to tell it, for knowing that the revealing of griefs, is as it were a renewing of sorrow, I have vowed therefore to conceal them, that I might not only feel the depth of everlasting discontentment, but despair of remedy? But whence are you? What fortune hath thrust you to this distress?

sp.speaker: Eumenides.
sp.p: I am going to Thessalie, to seek remedy for Endimion my dearest friend, who hath been cast into a dead sleep, almost these twenty years, waxing old, and ready for the grave, being almost but newly come forth of the cradle.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: You need not for recure travel far, for whoso can clearly see the bottom of this Fountain, shall have remedy for anything.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: That methinketh is unpossible, why what virtue can there be in water?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Yes, whosoever can shed the tears of a faithful Lover, shall obtain anything he would, read these words engraven about the brim.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Have you known this by experience, or is it placed here of purpose to delude men?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: I only would have experience of it, and then should there be an end of my misery. And then would I tell the strangest discourse that ever yet was heard.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Ah Eumenides.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: What lack you Gentleman, are you not well?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Yes Father, but a qualm that often cometh over my heart doth now take hold of me, but did never any Lovers come hither?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Lusters, but not Lovers; for often have I seen them weep, but never could I hear they saw the bottom.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Came there women also?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Some.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: What did they see?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: They all wept that the Fountain overflowed with tears, but so thick became the water with their tears, that I could scarce discern the brim, much less behold the bottom.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Be faithful Lovers so scant?

sp.speaker: Gerom.
sp.p: It seemeth so , for yet heard I never of any.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Ah Eumenides, how art thou perplexed? call to mind the beauty of thy sweet Mistress, and the depth of thy never-dying affections, how oft hast thou honoured her , not only without spot, but suspicion of falsehood? And how hardly hath she rewarded thee, without cause or colour of despite?

How secret hast thou been these seven years, that hast not, nor once darest not, to name her for discontenting her ? How faithful? that hast offered to die for her , to please her . Unhappy Eumenides.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Why Gentleman did you once love?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Once? Aye Father and ever shall.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Was she unkind, and you faithful?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: She of all women the most froward, and I of all creatures the most fond.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p:
You doted then, not loved: for affection is
grounded on virtue, and virtue is never peevish: or on Beauty, and Beauty loveth to be praised.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Aye but if all virtuous Ladies should yield to all that be loving, or all amiable gentlewomen entertain all that be amorous, their virtues would be accounted vices, and their beauties deformities, for that love can be but between two, and that not proceeding of him that is most faithful, but most fortunate.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: I would you were so faithful, that your tears might make you fortunate.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Yea father, if that my tears clear not this fountain, then may you swear it is but a mere mockery.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: So saith everyone yet, that wept.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Ah, I faint, I die. Ah sweet Semele let me alone, and dissolve by weeping into water.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: This affection seemeth strange, if he see nothing, without doubt this dissembling passeth, for nothing shall draw me from the belief.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Father, I plainly see the bottom, and there in white marble engraven these words, Ask one for all, and but one thing at all

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: O fortunate Eumenides, for so have I heard thee call thyself) let me see. I cannot discern any such thing. I think thou dreamest.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Ah Father thou art not a faithful lover, and therefore canst not behold it.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Then ask that I may be satisfied by the event, and thyself blessed.
Eum.

Ask? so I will : and what shall I do but ask, and whom should I ask but Semele, the possessing of whose person, is a pleasure that cannot come within the compass of comparison, whose golden locks seem most curious, when they seem most careless, whose sweet looks seem most alluring, when they are most chaste: and whose words the more virtuous they are,
the more amorous they be accounted. I pray thee fortune when I shall first meet with fair Semele, dash my delight with some light disgrace, lest embracing sweetness beyond measure, I take a surfeit without recure: let her practise her accustomed coyness, that I may diet myself upon my desires: otherwise the fulness of my joys will diminish the sweetness, and I shall perish by them before I possess them.

Why do I trifle the time in words? The least minute being spent in the getting of Semele, is more worth than the whole world: therefore let me ask. What now Eumenides? Whither art thou drawn? Hast thou forgotten both friendship and duty? Care of Endimion, and the commandment of Cynthia? Shall he die in a leaden sleep, because thou sleepest in a golden dream? Aye, let him sleep ever, so I slumber but one minute with Semele. Love knoweth neither friendship nor kindred.

Shall I not hazard the loss of a friend, for the obtaining of her for whom I would often lose myself? Fond Eumenides, shall the enticing beauty of a most disdainful Lady, be of more force than the rare fidelity of a tried friend? The love of men to women is a thing common, and of course: the friendship of man to man infinite and immortal. Tush, Semele doth possess my love. Aye but Endimion hath deserved it. I will help Endimion. I found Endimion unspotted in his truth. Aye but shall find Semele constant in her love. I will have Semele. What shall I do? Father thy gray hairs are Ambassadors of experience. Which shall I ask?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p:
Eumenides, release Endimion, for all things (friendship excepted) are subject to fortune: Love is but an eye worm, which only tickleth the head with hopes, and wishes: friendship the image of eternity,
in which there is nothing moveable, nothing mischievous. As much difference as there is between Beauty and Virtue, bodies and shadows, colours and life: so great odds is there between love and friendship.

Love is a Chameleon, which draweth nothing into the mouth but air, and nourisheth nothing in the body but lunges: believe me Eumenides, Desire dies in the same moment that Beauty sickens, and Beauty fadeth in the same instant that it flourisheth. When adversities flow, then love ebbs: but friendship standeth stiffly in storms. Time draweth wrinkles in a fair face, but addeth fresh colours to a fast friend, which neither heat, nor cold, nor misery, nor place, nor destiny, can alter or diminish. O friendship of all things the most rare, and therefore most rare because most excellent, whose comforts in misery is always sweet, and whose counsels in prosperity are ever fortunate. Vain love, that only coming near to friendship in name, would seem to be the same, or better, in nature.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Father I allow your reasons, and will therefore conquer mine own. Virtue shall subdue affections, wisdom lust, friendship beauty. Mistresses are in every place, and as common as Hares in Atho, Bees in Hybla, fowls in the air: but friends to be found, are like the Phoenix in Arabia, but one, or the Philadelph in Arays, never above two. I will have Endimion, sacred Fountain, in whose bowels are hidden divine secrets, I have increased your waters with the tears of unspotted thoughts and therefore let me receive the reward you promise: Endimion the truest friend to me, and faithfullest lover to Cynthia, is in such a dead sleep, that nothing can wake or move him.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Dost thou see anything?

sp.speaker: Eumenides.
sp.p:
I see in the same Pillar, these words:
When she whose figure of all is the perfectest, and never to be measured: always" one, yet never the same: still inconstant, yet never wavering, shall come and kiss Endimion in his sleep, he shall then rise, else never. This is strange.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: What see you else?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: There cometh over mine eyes either a dark mist, or upon the fountain a deep thickness: for I can perceive nothing. But how am I deluded? or what difficult nay impossible) thing is this?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Methinketh it easy.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Good father and how?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Is not a circle of all Figures the perfectest?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: And is not Cynthia of all circles the most absolute?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Is it not impossible to measure her , who still worketh by her influence, never standing at one stay?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Is she not always Cynthia, yet seldom in the same bigness, always wavering in her waxing or waning, that our bodies might the better be governed, our seasons the daylier give their increase, yet never to be removed from her course, as long as the heavens continue theirs?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: Then who can it be but Cynthia, whose virtues being all divine, must needs bring things to pass that be miraculous? Go, humble thyself to Cynthia, tell her the success, of which myself shall be a witness. And this assure thyself, that she that sent to find means for his safety, will now work her cunning.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p:
Cynthia How fortunate am I, if Cynthia be she that may
do it.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: How fond art thou, if thou do not believe it?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: I will hasten thither, that I may entreat on my knees for succour, and embrace in mine arms my friend.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: I will go with thee, for unto Cynthia must I discover all my sorrows, who also must work in me a contentment.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: May I now know the cause?

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: That shall be as we walk, and I doubt not but the strangeness of my tale will take away the tediousness of our journey.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.p: Let us go.

sp.speaker: Zon
sp.p: I follow.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p:
I Marvel Corsites giveth me so much liberty: all the world knowing his charge to be so high, and his nature to be most strange, who hath so ill entreated Ladies of great honour, that he hath not suffered them to look out of windows, much less to walk abroad: it may be he is in love with me, for (Endimion, hardhearted Endimion, excepted) what is he that is not enamoured of my beauty? But what respectest thou the love of all the world, Endimion hates thee. Alas poor Endimion, my malice hath exceeded my love: and thy faith to Cynthia quenched my affections. Quenched Tellus ? nay kindled them afresh; insomuch that I find scorching flames, for dead embers, and cruel encounters of war in my thoughts, instead of sweet parleys. Ah that I might once again see Endimion; accursed
girl, what hope hast thou to see Endimion? on whose head already are grown gray hairs, and whose life must yield to Nature, before Cynthia end her displeasure. Wicked Dipsas, and most devilish Tellus, the one for cunning too exquisite, the other for hate too intolerable. Thou wast commanded to weave the stories and Poetries, wherein were showed both examples and punishments of tattling tongues, and thou hast only embroidered the sweet face of Endimion, devises of love, melancholy imaginations, and what not, out of thy work, that thou shouldest study to pick out of thy mind. But here cometh Corsites, I must seem yielding and stout, full of mildness, yet tempered with a Majesty: for if I be too flexible, I shall give him more hope than I mean, if too froward, enjoy less liberty than I would, love him I cannot, and therefore will practise that which is most contrary to our sex, to dissemble.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Fair Tellus, I perceive you rise with the Lark, and to yourself sing with the Nightingale.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: My Lord I have no play-fellow but fancy, being barred of all company I must question with myself, and make my thoughts my friends.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I would you would account my thoughts also your friends, for they be such as are only busied in wondering at your beauty, and wisdom: and some such as have esteemed your fortune too hard, and divers of that kind that offer to set you free, if you will set them free.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: There are no colours so contrary as white and black, nor Elements so disagreeing as fire and water, nor anything so opposite as men's thoughts and their words.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
He that gave Cassandra the gift of prophesying with the curse, that spake she never so true, she should never be believed, hath I think poisoned the fortune of men, that uttering the extremities of their inward passions,
are always suspected of outward perjuries.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: Well Corsites I will flatter myself, and believe you. What would you do to enjoy my love?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Set all the Ladies of the Castle free, and make you the pleasure of my life: more I cannot do, less I will not.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: These be great words, and fit your calling: for Captains must promise things impossible. But will you do one thing for all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Anything sweet Tellus, that am ready for all.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: You know that on the Lunary bank sleepeth Endimion.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: If you will remove him from that place by force, and convey him into some obscure cave by policy: I give you here the faith of an unspotted virgin, that you only shall possess me as a lover, and in spite of malice, have me for a wife.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Remove him Tellus ? Yes Tellus he shall be removed, and that so soon, as thou shalt as much commend my diligence as my force. I go.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p: Stay, will yourself attempt it?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Aye Tellus: as I would have none partaker of my sweet love, so shall none be partners of my labours: but I pray thee go at your best leisure, for Cynthia beginneth to rise, and if she discover our love we both perish, for nothing pleaseth her but the fairness of virginity. All things must be not only without lust, but without suspicion of lightness.

sp.speaker: Tellus.
sp.p: I will depart, and go you to Endimion .

sp.speaker: Corsites.
sp.p: I fly Tellus, being of all men the most fortunate.

sp.speaker: Tel.
sp.p:
Simple Corsites, I have set thee about a task being but a man, that the gods themselves cannot perform: for little
dost thou know how heavy his head lies, how hard his fortune: but such shifts must women have to deceive men, and under colour of things easy, entreat that which is impossible: otherwise we should be cumbered with importunities, oaths, sighs, letters, and all implements of love, which to one resolved to the contrary, are most loathsome. I will in, and laugh with the other Ladies at Corsites sweating.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Will thy master never awake?

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: No, I think he sleeps for a wager: but how shall we spend the time? Sir Tophas is so far in love that he pineth in his bed, and cometh not abroad?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: But here cometh Epi, in a peeling chafe.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: A pox of all false Proverbs, and were a Proverb a Page, I would have him by the ears.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Why art thou angry?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why? you know it is said, the tide tarrieth no man.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I A monstrous lie; for I was tide two hours, and tarried for one to unloose me.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Alas poor Epi.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Poor? No, no , you base conceited slaves, I am a most complete Gentleman, although I be in disgrace with sir Tophas.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Art thou out with him.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Aye, because I cannot get him a lodging with Endimion, he would fain take a nap for forty or fifty years.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: A short sleep, considering our long life.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is he still in love?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: In love? why he doth nothing but make Sonnets.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Canst thou remember any one of his Poems?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Aye this is one. The beggar Love that knows not where to lodge: At last within my heart when I slept, he crept, I waked, and so my fancies began to fodge.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That is a very long Verse.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why the other was short, the first is called from the thumb to the little finger, the second from the little finger to the elbow, and some he hath made to reach to the crown of his head, and down again to the sole of his foot: it is set to the tune of the black Saunce, ratio est, because Dipsas is a black Saint.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Very wisely, but pray thee Epi how art thou complete, and being from thy Master what occupation wilt thou take?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No my hearts, I am an absolute Microcosmus, a petty world of myself, my library is my head, for I have no other books but my brains: my wardrobe on my back, for I have no more apparel than is on my body; my armoury at my finger ends, for I use no other Artillery than my nails; my treasure in my purse. Sic omnia mea mecum porto

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Now sirs, my Palace is paved with grass, and tiled with stars: for celo tegitur qui non habet vrnam, he that hath no house, must lie in the yard.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A brave resolution. But how wilt thou spend thy time?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Not in any Melancholy sort, for mine exercise I will walk horses.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Too bad.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Why is it not said: It is good walking when one hath his horse in his hand?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Worse, and worse, but how wilt thou live?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
By angling; O it is a stately occupation to stand
four hours in a cold Morning, and to have his nose bitten with frost, before his bait be mumbled with a Fish.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: A rare attempt, but wilt thou never travel?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes in a Western barge, when with a good wind and lusty pugs, one may go ten miles in two days.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thou art excellent at thy choice, but what pastime wilt thou use, none?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes the quickest of all.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What dice?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, when I am in haste, twenty one games at Chess, to pass a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: A life for a little Lord, and full of quickness.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Tush, let me alone, but I must needs see if I can find where Endimion lieth, and then go to a certain fountain hard by , where they say faithful Lovers shall have all things they will ask. If I can find out any of these, ego et Magister meus erimus in tutoI and my Master shall be friends. He is resolved to weep some three or four pailfuls, to avoid the rheum of love that wambleth in his stomach.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: Shall we never see thy Master Dares?

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Yes, let us go now, for tomorrow Cynthia will be there.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I will go with you. But how shall we see for the Watch?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Tush let me alone, I will begin to them. Masters God speed you.

sp.speaker: 1. Watch.
sp.p: Sir boy, we are all sped already.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: So methinks, for they smell all of drink, like a beggars beard.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: But I pray sirs, may we see Endimion?

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.p:
No, we are commanded in Cynthias name
that no man shall see him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: No man? Why we are but boys.

sp.speaker: 1. Watch.
sp.p: Mass neighbours he says true, for if I swear I will never drink my liquor by the quart, and yet call for two pints, I think with a safe conscience I may carouse both.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Pithily, and to the purpose.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.p: Tush, tush neighbours, take me with you.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: This will grow hot.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Let them alone.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.p: If I say to my Wife, Wife I will have no raisins in my pudding, she puts in currants, small raisins are raisins, and boys are men. Even as my wife should have put no raisins in my pudding, so shall there no boys see Endimion.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Learnedly.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Let Master Constable speak: I think he is the wisest among you.

sp.speaker: Master Constable.
sp.p: You know Neighbours, it is an old said saw, Children and Fools speak true.

sp.speaker: All say.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mast. Const.
sp.p: Well, there you see the men be the fools, because it is provided from the children.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Mast. Const.
sp.p: Then say I Neighbours, that children must not see Endimion, because children and fools speak true.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: O wicked application.

sp.speaker: Samias.
sp.p: Scurvily brought about.

sp.speaker: 1. Watch.
sp.p: Nay he says true, and therefore till Cynthia have been here he shall not be uncovered. Therefore away.

sp.speaker: Dares.
sp.p: A watch quoth you? a man may watch seven years for a wise word, and yet go without it. Their wits are all as rusty as their bills. But come on Master Constable shall we have a song before we go?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Corsites.
sp.p: I am come in sight of the Lunary bank, without doubt Tellus doteth upon me, and; cunningly that I might not perceive her love, she hath set me to a task that is done before it is begun. Endimion, you must change your pillow, and if you be not weary of sleep, I will carry you where at ease you shall sleep your fill. It were good that without more ceremonies I took him, lest being espied, I be entrapped, and so incur the displeasure of Cynthia, who commonly setteth watch that Endimion have no wrong.

What now, is your Mastership so heavy? or are you nailed to the ground? Not stir one whit? then use all thy force though he feel it and wake. What stone still? turned I think to earth, with lying so long on the earth. Didst not thou Corsites before Cynthia pull up a tree, that forty years was fastened with roots and wreathed in knots to the ground? Didst not thou with main force pull open the iron gates, which no Ram or Engine could move? Have my weak thoughts made brawn-fallen my strong arms? or is it the nature of love or the Quintessence of the mind to breed numbness, or litheness, or I know not what, languishing in my joints and sinews, being but the base strings of my body? Or doth the remembrance of Tellus so refine my spirits into a matter so subtle and divine, that the other fleshy parts cannot work whilst they muse? Rest thyself, rest thyself: nay, rent thyself in pieces Corsites, and strive in spite of love, fortune, and nature, to lift up this dulled body, heavier than lead, and more senseless than death.
But what are these so fair fiends that cause my hairs to stand upright, and spirits to fall down? hags, out alas, Nymphs I crave pardon. Aye me, out what do I here.

div2.stage: The Fairies daunce, and with a Song pinch him, and he falleth asleepe, they kisse Endimion and depart.
Cynthia, Floscula, Semele, Panelion, Zonte, Pythagoras, Gyptes, Corsites.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: You see Pythagoras what ridiculous opinions you hold, and I doubt not but you are now of another mind.

sp.speaker: Pythag.
sp.p: Madam, I plainly perceive that the perfection of your brightness, hath pierced through the thickness that covered my mind; insomuch that I am no less glad to be reformed, than ashamed to remember my grossness.

sp.speaker: Gyptes.
sp.p: They are thrice fortunate that live in your Palace, where Truth is not in colours but life, virtues, not in imagination, but execution.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: I have always studied to have rather living virtues than painted Gods, the body of Truth, than the tomb. But let us walk to Endimion, it may be it lieth in your Arts to deliver him, as for Eumenides I fear he is dead.

sp.speaker: Pytha.
sp.p: I have alleged all the natural reasons I can for such a long sleep.

sp.speaker: Gyptes.
sp.p: I can do nothing till I see him.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Come Floscula, I am sure you are glad that you shall behold Endimion.

sp.speaker: Flose.
sp.p: I were blessed if I might have him recovered.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Are you in love with his person.

sp.speaker: Flosc.
sp.p: No, but with his virtue.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: What say you Semele?

sp.speaker: Semele.
sp.p: Madam, I dare say nothing for fear I offend.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Belike you cannot speak except you be spiteful. But as good be silent as saucy. Panelion, what punishment were fit for Semele, in whose speech and thoughts, is only contempt and; sourness?

sp.speaker: Pane.
sp.p: I love not Madam to give any judgment. Yet sith your Highness commandeth, I think, to commit her tongue close prisoner to her mouth.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Agreed; Semele, if thou speak this twelve-month, thou shalt forfeit thy tongue. Behold Endimion, alas poor Gentleman, hast thou spent thy youth in sleep, that once vowed all to my service. Hollow eyes? gray hairs? wrinkled cheeks? and decayed limbs? Is it destiny, or deceit that hath brought this to pass? If the first, who could prevent thy wretched stars. If the latter, I would I might know thy cruel enemy. I favoured thee Endimion for thy honour, thy virtues, thy affections: but to bring thy thoughts within the compass of thy fortunes, I have seemed strange, that I might have thee stayed, and now are thy days ended before my favour begin. But whom have we here, is it not Corsites?

sp.speaker: Zon.
sp.p: It is, but more like a Leopard than a man.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Awake him. How now Corsites, what make you here? How came you deformed? Look on thy hands, and then thou seest the picture of thy face.

sp.speaker: Corsites.
sp.p: Miserable wretch, and accursed. How am I deluded? Madam, I ask pardon for my offence, and you see my fortune deserveth pity.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: Speak on , thy offence cannot deserve greater punishment: but see thou rehearse the truth, else shalt thou not find me as thou wishest me.

sp.speaker: Corsites.
sp.p: I Madam, as it is no offence to be in love being a man mortal, so I hope can it be no shame to tell with whom, my Lady being heavenly. Your Majesty committed to my charge fair Tellus, whose beauty in the same moment took my heart captive, that I undertook to carry her body prisoner. Since that time have I found such combats in my thoughts between love and duty, reverence and affection, that I could neither endure the conflict, nor hope for the conquest.

sp.speaker: Cynth.
sp.p: In love? A thing far unfitting the name of a Captain, and (as I thought) the tough and unsmoothed nature of Corsites. But forth.

sp.speaker: Corsi.
sp.p: I Feeling this continual war, I thought rather by parley to yield, than by certain danger to perish, I unfolded to Tellus the depth of my affections, and framed my tongue to utter a sweet tale of love, that was wont to sound nothing but threats of war.
